events.target_title: GIMP 2.10 Crashing even after reinstall
shotwell makes copies of raw images either with _embedded.jpeg or _shotwell.jpeg in the name.

note.body:
I just wanted to add a scenario that maybe hasn't been covered here. I only recently switched to Ubuntu from MacOS. I have an existing library of more than 50,000 RAW images. All of these images are backed up to a Dropbox account.

I like Shotwell but, every time I start it up, it starts trying to generate embedded.jpg files for every one of my 50,000 plus RAW files. And of course, my Dropbox software automatically tries to upload these. I would soon run out of storage if I let this continue.

I do understand that Shotwell (like every other RAW file manager) needs to create preview images, but could it create those in a separate directory, perhaps allow the user to choose the size of the preview files and, maybe only preview the most recently accessed files? Yes, I guess I'm describing Lightroom. :-)

Sadly, I can't use Shotwell until something like this is implemented.

note.body:
@ZanderBrown Thanks for the reply. I just now realized the formatting issue. The [dia.patch](/uploads/61ec22ce874a0b67aa6b8306fab48cf9/dia.patch) is a diff containing a more easy way to read what was changed. It is a very simple code, the main difficult being the automated migration path.

Do you have a situation in mind about this change breaking packages ext? I did not use any extra distro specific libs. I use the Linux example, but these XDG dirs are also documented for Windows and MacOS. It is done automatically by glib.

Regarding these change, there is also an alternative solution of "using the old config if it exists", as in check if "$HOME/.dia" exists; if it does, use it. Otherwise, check/use folders as XDG Base Dir Support. No migration in this case, though.

What do you think I should do about this merge request? Should I submit a new one without these formatting issues?

What do we need next?

xdg-base-dir-spec-support doesn't migrate python plugins

note.body:
Hey @tpo! Did you run `autogen.sh --with-python`? The python migration path is done on access, when it tries to load python scripts (**python-startup.py** file). If you don't compile enabling python, then it does not work.

The idea for this was simple, do not migrate something you are not going to use it.

events.target_title: the config migration from ~/.dia to  XDG BaseDirs shouldn't complain when there's nothing to migrate

note.body: @neduard Hey! The reason for this is that in file `lib/dia_dirs.c`, line `173`, there is a `!g_rename(oldloc, newloc)` instead of `g_rename(oldloc, newloc) == -1`. That is the reason why it messaged this warning in your case. It is easily fixed, but there are some other important stuff about this, I will follow here !5.

events.target_title: Add support for the XDG Base Directory Support with an automated migration path.

note.body:
Hey @ZanderBrown & @neduard! I saw the issues and can explain why:

#20 happens when dia is compiled without the `--with-python`. The migration is done on access, within `python-startup.py`. This file is read only with the option. I will try to defend this: why the user would use a python folder without the compilation flag? The python plugins would have never worked in the first place, so nothing should be lost. But then again, this is a folder that exists for dia.

#21 is a dumb if-clause mistake. Check the related issue and the fix. The files/dirs were correctly migrated on the first run, though.

Now, about the migration, I can understand where @creiter wants to go, but I do want to point out that you would need to manage multiple dirs (`$XDG_DATA_HOME/dia`, `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/dia`, `$HOME/.dia`). Where should the user save his newly created shape? There are two possible dirs for this. Even worst, it would be affected if the location was there or not and by the order of precedence. By auto-migrating stuff, you can just use a single location. The migration code would then be removed after a while and the new location would be the only one supported.

Now, something that I realized when looking at #21 is that the migration could be better. At the moment, I try to rename dirs and files to the new location. What if there is a conflict between files/dirs from old location and the new one? An user who saves a shape in `$HOME/.dia/shapes` that also has the same name of one in `$XDG_DATA_HOME/dia/shapes`? The current migration will send a warning, but because will try to rename the `shapes` dir for the new location. Maybe I should do it for files only and only send warnings on this type of conflict.

What made you change your mind on this? Do you foresee more issues from this? Dia is still going to do its first big release - 1.0, right? That's feels like the best moment to try to push something like this. But, of course, you do what you think will be the best decision for this. I am just trying to support the XDG Base Dir Spec for as many projects as I can.

events.target_title: double.MIN value is not as expected (by me)

note.body: When in doubt, I'm always in favor to follow the OpenGroup definitions -- so I'm in favor of rejecting this path. We should – however – think about Juerg's suggestion of augmenting the API with clearer names, although I'm slightly against completely deprecating the .MIN. I convert a lot of POSIX C code to Vala and am glad that often it's just a matter of changing very little to make this working.

events.target_title: posix: add *at calls, e.g. openat(2) and related constants

note.body:
Well, technically `_POSIX_C_SOURCE=200809L` would be the most appropriate `#define`, but this can get ugly once you start using more of those which might step onto each others toes.

I rather suggest using the more wide granular feature test macros, such as `_GNU_SOURCE` and `_XOPEN_SOURCE`.

events.target_title: Add ability to view data in binary
Silently fails to display tar contents after a file with xattrs is encountered

note.body:
@paobac I have recreated this with the packages in Ubuntu 18.04 and 18.10, they are versions 3.28.0-1ubuntu1 and 3.29.90-1 following the exact steps in this bug.  When file-roller opens the archive it only shows files up to the file which has extended attributes, that file, and all after it, are not in the file listing.

Please ensure that when you attempt the recreate the second file (in the case of the example this is usr/bin/mtr-packet) has extended capabilities.  You can check this with:
```
$ getcap /usr/bin/mtr-packet 
/usr/bin/mtr-packet = cap_net_raw+ep
```
If the `getcap` command returns no output then you will not have a valid test.

Alternatively you could create a test file with capabilities with `sudo setcap cap_net_raw+ep foo` and include the file foo in the middle of your file list when creating the tar file in step 1.

events.target_title: Debugging Help
Debugging Help

note.body:
Hey thank you for getting back to me! I appreciate it! 

Okay the VTE_DEBUG=updates,misc,io ./src/app/vte-2.91 helps a ton. My issue was that I hadn't been able to find the executable (oof) so I was installing my version of vte over the stock version (which is why I was doing it in a vm, using sudo, and rebooting). This is much better!

As for your second paragraph, its kind of going over my head (sorry im just a college kid so I'm still learning). I followed the steps on the link you gave me and just succeeded in making a second terminal pop up. If you have the time, could you give me a step by step of what you type when you want to debug vte in gdb (or however you debug it)?

Also just out of curiosity, in vte.cc I want to make the function
bool is_at_bottom_of_feed() (aka I want to see whether or not I've scrolled down all the way to where I can type commands). I imagine it has to do with m_screen but I don't quite know how it works. If you know any tips just off the top of your head that would be awesome, if it's complicated to explain though no worries; I'll get it eventually! Again, thanks for the help!

Also how would i get the current height of the terminal? i think its default is like 24.

events.target_title: Debugging Help

note.body:
`This is what I'm doing most of the time, on my real system :) If I mess it up big time, I fix it from an xterm :-D.`

You are much braver than I haha! I'm sticking to my vm :)

And you can use printf()!!! It's a miracle! Believe it or not I didn't realize this, and that's why I wanted to get debug working so bad was so I could use _vte_debug_print to see what was going on. printf() has made vte wonderful to work with. I feel kinda silly for not realizing it would work. I was only asking about gdb because it was what I assumed you guys used and I was willing to put up with it if absolutely necessary.

Thank you for all the information, and with printf() I was able to complete the scavenger hunt you gave me in a few minutes! I really appreciate all the help you gave me and I wouldn't have been able to finish my little project without it! I made a fork of vte (https://github.com/arprince/vte) where you can press shift + pgup, pgdn in order to scroll to the last place you pressed enter. I wanted to make it because I do a lot of debugging in C++ and I hate scrolling all the way up for miles in order to see my syntax errors. And also I saw that you're the main maintainer for the terminal and I wanted to say thank you for doing that! I think it's safe to say that all of linux-world appreciates your work!

Again, thanks a ton!

You are right. I misread the source. C0 ST is just misinterpreted as a independent control sequence and linux VT does just interprets it as a unknown but ignored sequence. Not really robust but it seems to work for now.

Sorry for the noise.

events.target_title: Mismapped Sequence ESC [ > (number) p

note.body:
I'm currently working on documenting how modern terminals work. This is still very much work in progress at https://terminalguide.netlify.com/ and https://github.com/terminalguide/terminalguide/. (Feedback and corrections very much appreciated)

So this is not random chance in the sense that i'm looking at every implemented sequence in vte (among other implementations). But it is a bit of random chance in what i'm currently reporting because i've not yet finished and reporting is of course additional work and it's often unclear if divergence from xterm is intended. (also i will miss things by random chance, hopefully with a reasonable low chance^^)

Things that are currently looking like vte does something odd, that does not match what other implementations do at all, include handling of ESC Z which everyone else uses as "Return Terminal ID (DECID)" but vte seems to prefer to implement ecma-64 SCI which no other terminal i looked at does.

Also DCS $r seems to be only intended to be used as terminal to host communication but vte aliases it to DCS $q.

And there are of course sequences where i'm sure you know about conflicting usage like osc 6 with different interpretations between vte and xterm.

events.target_title: Mismapped Sequence ESC [ > (number) p

note.body:
I've updated my docs regarding DECRPSS.

Yes, i meant ECMA-48. Regarding DA1 as a replacement of DECID, from my limited sample all terminals do support DA1 with the same reply. So that works for applications that know that DECID should not be used. Do you expect that SCI will be usable and used in the future. It's officially reserved for future standardization(unlikely to happen?) and not really likely to get grabbed by any terminal because e.g. xterm will likely prefer to be historically accurate than implement some possible future usage.

Generally i would expect future usages that restrict terminals from being historically accurate to be somewhat unlikely to get traction unless it's some kind of fix where the old sequence must be reused to get the intended effect.

events.target_title: intel_backlight not included in available kernal interfaces list in gsd-backlight-helper.c

note.body:
I seem to have an issue with this same problem:

I own a laptop with hybrid intel/AMD (RX470) graphics. Recently, the amdgpu driver has learned not to register a backlight device in /sys/class/backlight when not connected to any displays, so only intel_backlight shows up there. 

However, when I try to adjust screen brightness unter GNOME, there is a discernable pause, as for some reason the (runtime suspended) dGPU gets woken up by g-s-d, presumably to query it for backlight devices? This is unnecessary and together with the unstable state of amdgpu causes frequent crashes on my device. In the end, g-s-d ends up changing the backlight through intel_backlight, because there is no other device available, but waking up the other GPU for nothing is really unnecessary and should be avoided.

events.target_title: intel_backlight not included in available kernal interfaces list in gsd-backlight-helper.c

note.body: OK, I did what you asked and it seems that a) both methods lead to the same 'pause' in execution and b) that neither method does anything before the dGPU has had a chance to power cycle and go back to sleep if invoked in quick succession. So probably more of a kernel issue than a GNOME thing...

events.target_title: intel_backlight not included in available kernal interfaces list in gsd-backlight-helper.c

note.body:
OK, here is an update, may it is a GNOME issue after all!

I did some more digging in order to better isolate the problem (amdgpu vs i915 vs acpi vs GNOME vs X11 ...) and noticed something interesting: I booted my system to the GDM login screen (standard wayland GDM). Then, instead of signing into a graphical session, I used Ctrl+Alt+F2 to get to a tty and log in there (no graphical shell, obviously). Here, I was able to issue `#echo X > /sys/class/backlight/intel_backlight/brightness` without any issues (no lag, no dmesg weirdness, no crashes).

I then switched back to GDM and logged into a Wayland session. Here, adjusting the backlight via either the slider in the menu or via `#echo X > /sys/class/backlight/intel_backlight/brightness` caused immediate lagginess (on the order of several seconds), amdgpu errors in dmesg and finally a system crash. In an X session the crash comes on the first messing with brightness, in Wayland it takes several "tries". 

Without a graphical session, no crashes whatsoever happen. So, maybe it is not strictly speaking a (pure) kernel issue? I'd be happy to help debug this further and split off whatever related bug reports someone more knowledgeable about these things might suggest.

events.target_title: intel_backlight not included in available kernal interfaces list in gsd-backlight-helper.c

note.body:
Bit of background on my issue & setup: My laptop has a hybrid intel/amd gpu setup. The internal display is only connected to the intel gpu and is the only one I (currently) use. However, connected exclusively to the amd gpu, there are also a DP, eDP and HDMI display, all correctly diabled by the amdgpu driver at runtime, because there are no displays connected there. 

My theory as to what's happening here is that GNOME sees those displays and tries to adjust their brightness when I adjust that on the main screen. That is of course doomed to failure, as there are no backlight devices that can possibly do anything to those (non existant) displays. Then, this meddling somehow causes a crash. Does that make any sense?

events.target_title: Memory leak full image when loading

note.body:
I did it roughly with these instructions:

```
BASE=$HOME/memleak-testproj
PREFIX=$BASE/install

git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gdk-pixbuf/ $BASE/gdk-pixbuf
git clone https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/librsvg $BASE/librsvg

#Build gdk pixbuf first
cd $BASE/gdk-pixbuf
meson . _build --prefix=$PREFIX
ninja -C _build
ninja -C _build install

# export the required variables, that librsvg installs its loader to the file
export GDK_PIXBUF_MODULEDIR=$PREFIX/lib/gdk-pixbuf-2.0/2.10.0/loaders/
export PKG_CONFIG_PATH="${PREFIX}/lib/pkgconfig${PKG_CONFIG_PATH:+:}${PKG_CONFIG_PATH}"
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH="${PREFIX}/lib${LD_LIBRARY_PATH:+:}${LD_LIBRARY_PATH}"
export PATH="${PREFIX}/bin${PATH:+:}${PATH}"

# now compile librsvg
cd $BASE/librsvg
./autogen.sh --prefix=$PREFIX
make -j
make install
```

If you want to call the reproducer now, you can spawn it in another terminal, but you have to export **all** mentioned variables again!

But it doesn't work out. I've respected gdk-pixbuf's `loaders.cache`, I've taken care of the libraries. When I put some `printf` into `gdk_pixbuf__svg_image_load_increment`, it'll get printed. So the actual function should work out fine, but it fails on every commit during bisect.

Select by Color tool does not select pixel(s) or area(s) of pixel(s)

note.body:
I encountered this issue with the PortableApps release. I was unable to reproduce the issue with the official 64-bit release, so it could be a 32-bit issue, or it could be a problem with the PortableApps compile.

Windows 10, PortableApps, v2.10.6

With threshold set to 0.0 and mode set to Composite (or R/G/B), the Select by Color tool appears to be incapable of selecting certain colors.

I have also encountered odd cases where an image has multiple layers but only one set to visible. Trying to selecting a color with "Sample merged" enabled does not work on some colors, but it does work if I disable "Sample merged" and select the same color.

Reproduction steps:

1. Create a new document with a black background.
2. Use the pencil tool to draw a grey area (color #808080)
3. Choose the Select by Color tool.
4. Set Threshold to 0.0. Mode to Composite.
5. Click on the black area.
6. Click on the newly drawn grey area.

Expected result: The tool selects the black area, then selects the grey area.

Actual result: The tool selects the black area. Clicking on the grey area deselects the black area but does not select the grey area.

Changing threshold to 0.1 makes the composite mode work as expected, which makes me think there is some sort of rounding bug.

Update: Changing precision from 8-bit integer to any other setting also seems to fix the issue.

This problem does not occur with the Fuzzy Select Tool.

events.target_title: Select by Color tool does not select pixel(s) or area(s) of pixel(s)

note.body:
It looks like progress has already been made on this, but I'll clarify things anyway in case the information is of use to anyone.

The colors of the pencil-drawn pixels in my steps are identical. The issue is not with Gimp failing to select parts of the drawn area, but that it selects nothing at all. Not even the pixel being clicked on is selected.

Precision errors in conversion would explain this so I expect Ell's patch to work for me. I'll verify that this is the case as soon as there is a new Windows release. I managed to reproduce the issue with the official installer (2.10.8 / x64 / Win10) by performing the same steps as before while also ensuring that "sample-merged" is unchecked.

So I had to test it myself on Windows 2008 server and saw the same error.

After playing around, I found a workaround solution to this problem so that HELP would work again.
The workaround is described in details in post number 3: [here](https://gimplearn.net/viewtopic.php?p=27682#p27682).

This error was present in GIMP 2.10.12 as well on Windows 2008.

Could not reproduce this error on Linux/Ubuntu (also GIMP 2.10.12).

connection subscription, improve docs on errors

note.body:
I am most likely not well enough acquainted with all these details in glib, but this was not clear to me at all.  Then rather say that this value us guaranteed to never be zero.  

For us reading the documentation to do a proper implementation of glib features and who does not know all about the gory details inside glib, such details helps. And it helps us evaluate what kind of error checks are needed to ensure the program behaves as expected.

events.target_title: connection subscription, improve docs on errors

note.body:
(moving my "global" comment in here)

Fair points ... but ... `g_dbus_connection_signal_subscribe()` calls `g_return_val_if_fail()` in the very beginning, which will return 0 in case of any of these failures.  A claim saying "This function can never fail" would then be even more confusing - it does have 9 cases where it might return 0.

Yes, it might be considered a programmers error if any of them occurs.  But when you're working in multi-threaded programs, there might be some cases where some of these 9 cases may occur (most likely the connection itself has been "destroyed") - in which there will be errors spit out to the logs/console which isn't necessarily that easy to relate to a specific place in the program using this function. Which makes the debugging harder.

By stating the return value is expected to be > 0 on success or 0 on failure will at least give a much better hint something didn't go as expected. And the program using this function can better know how to act if things didn't work out.  Some might want to close and shutdown the program, others might want to check if the connection is intact and re-establish it if it can and retry.  Both behaviours are valid in their own context.

note.body:
I'm a little confused by the above comments. Currently, one must press escape twice to cancel out of the search, and then a third time to close the file chooser dialog. What I'm presuming the reporter wants to see—and what I certainly want to see—is that one only need press escape once to cancel out of the search, and then once again to close the dialog.

I'm not sure I see any reason why one should press escape twice to cancel out of the search, as it is. The first escape press doesn't seem to have any effect, either, as far as I can tell—you can still modify the search term, or select a file with Enter, regardless of whether escape has been pressed once or not.

events.target_title: FileChooser: allow use of backspace to move to parent directory
FileChooser: Allow disabling recursive search

note.body:
I don't want to be the kind of user who complains "this new feature **broke my workflow**; bring back the old behaviour immediately!", and not the least because I know this kind of response drives a wedge between users and developers.

I'm not opposed to recursive search in principle. If I could have recursive search happen nigh-instantaneously, or without hammering the disk, I'd be perfectly happy to do so (as long as the current directory is searched first, which is indeed I think the case). I'm not really optimistic that this is reasonably possible, however, at least not with my hardware, and I'd really like to implore GTK designers to honestly consider disabling recursive search.

My use case: typical software programmer, for whom the file chooser is most relevant when I'm using Geany to open a file from somewhere in my large but well-organized project. Without the overhead of recursive search, I can quickly navigate to a file I have in mind: ctrl-O, alt-up, alt-up, type half a folder name, press enter, type half a file name, press enter, and all of these steps happen nigh-instantaneously. With the overhead of recursive search, I have to wait as long as a couple of seconds for the listview to repopulate each time I search. Yes, my disk is slow, but with light-weight software, it's perfectly capable of being fast enough.

Again, I really have no inherent objections to recursive search. I could see it possibly being more useful to me than the lack of recursive search, but the disadvantages outweigh the advantages for me, and (it seems) for many others.

note.body:
Now I'm really confused.

I started tests with 2.10.6 from official installer. Setting `GIMP_NO_ASYNC_DRAWABLE_PREVIEWS` did not help.

Disabling layer previews helped, no crash. 
Disabling OpenCL also helped.

However, now after the tests I'm completely unable to replicate the bug. I even replaced my userprofile with the one I posted here, but nothing, not a single crash. I didn't change anything except the two prefs, and now even setting them back, GIMP doesn't crash anymore.

Is it possible GIMP keeps some configs outside %APPDATA%/Roaming/GIMP/ and %APPDATA%/Local/GIMP? Or is it possible that OpenCL has now stricter checks about which GPUs it will really be used?

note.body:
Ah sorry :) See below. 

Suspect not client related at all, just looking to mitigate what is probably VPN server side issue. Perhaps UDP connection tracking of the VPN service, or a device in front of it, is overwhelmed, as the problem varies according to time of day, but not within my power to fix that.

I can verify the VPN connection is really using UDP (tcpdump). When a TCP connection hangs, a new one can be created without resetting the VPN connection, and there is no log info which suggests the client side is aware of a problem (I don't have access to the VPN server logs). Another observation is the problem appears to be related to time of day - most likely the UDP connection tracking of the VPN service, which is behind perimeter firewalls, is overwhelmed. Again, server side, nothing in my control.

So forcing TCP works via ``--no-dtls``, if not a 'nice' solution, seems to work well.

```
richard@green:~$ openconnect --version
OpenConnect version v7.08-3
Using GnuTLS. Features present: PKCS#11, RSA software token, HOTP software token, TOTP software token, Yubikey OATH, System keys, DTLS
richard@green:~$ which openconnect
/usr/sbin/openconnect
richard@green:~$ dpkg -l | grep openconnect
rc  libopenconnect2:amd64                                       5.02-1                                      amd64        open client for Cisco AnyConnect VPN - shared library
ii  libopenconnect5:amd64                                       7.08-3                                      amd64        open client for Cisco AnyConnect VPN - shared library
ii  network-manager-openconnect                                 1.2.4-1                                     amd64        network management framework (OpenConnect plugin core)
ii  network-manager-openconnect-gnome                           1.2.4-1                                     amd64        network management framework (OpenConnect plugin GNOME GUI)
ii  openconnect                                                 7.08-3                                      amd64        open client for Cisco AnyConnect VPN
richard@green:~$ cat /etc/issue
Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS \n \l

richard@green:~$ 
```

events.target_title: Make --no-dtls an option

note.body:
For anyone reading this who has a similar issue to solve right now, you can force TCP on Linux by adding a firewall rule:

```
iptables -I OUTPUT -d <remote vpn gateway> -p udp --dport 443 -j REJECT
```

__vte_prompt_command doesn't escape control characters in $PWD
__vte_prompt_command doesn't escape control characters in $PWD

note.body:
Ah, sorry I didn't remember there was still Bugzilla as well.

I see I was mistakenly looking at only which characters might *validly* end the sequence.  Yes, it looks as if most control characters will interrupt the sequence: all of C1 and not all but many in C0.  Since control characters won't be displayed in the window title anyway, it seems safest (and easiest) to just strip out all of them.

Here's a patch, though I'm not sure how to test it in a non-UTF-8 locale: [0001-vte.sh-Replace-control-chars-for-window-title.patch](/uploads/a11444227648a7898c9ecb7eb1213b15/0001-vte.sh-Replace-control-chars-for-window-title.patch)

events.target_title: __vte_prompt_command doesn't escape control characters in $PWD

note.body:
Thanks for the help!  `[[:cntrl:]]` was what I first considered, but I wasn't sure about its coverage or how it reacted to locale changes — and the vte source clearly has a bunch of explicit characters so I was initially trying to match just those, until I decided it was better to expand it to include all of C0 and C1.  Now I understand better and I think `[[:cntrl:]]` is probably the best way to do this.

> Note that `shopt` and `globasciiranges` are bashism, whereas this script needs to work for both bash and zsh.

The `__vte_prompt_command` function is Bash-only: see lines 58-61.  Zsh gets `__vte_osc7` only.

> Could you please elaborate on how it works in UTF-8? It seems to work for me at first glimpse (on bash, with UTF-8), but bash's manual at globasciiranges says "as if in the traditional C locale when performing comparisons", but the traditional C locale does byte-by-byte comparison and not UTF-8. So I might easily be missing a test case where it fails; or we'd need to more closely study what bash does to confirm that it indeed properly does Unicode range matching on UTF-8 input (and forgets to document it).

You're right that its behaviour doesn't seem to quite match the documentation.  globasciiranges just causes characters to be compared numerically (in Bash, lib/glob/smatch.c:rangecmp_wc), but the input is still treated as multibyte characters rather than raw bytes.  Using `LC_ALL=C` instead of globasciiranges does indeed break the ranges because `$'\u80'` (and above) come out as multiple characters then.

> testing in non-UTF-8 locales

This was helpful, thanks.  I got a couple set up and tested with ISO 8859-1 and KOI8-R.  Interestingly, I also tried to set up a whole GNOME session (as a fresh user account) with a non-UTF-8 locale, but gnome-terminal-server won't start at all without a UTF-8 locale: "gnome-terminal-server[26821]: Non UTF-8 locale (ISO-8859-1) is not supported!"  Maybe other users of vte still support other encodings?

> Also the replacement character U+FFFD (hardwired in UTF-8) needs to be something else. I guess it's okay to just drop such characters.

Good point.  With the interesting behaviour of `$''` quoting you pointed out, we could show the replacement character only when available and drop it otherwise:

```bash
replacement=$'\ufffd'
[[ ${#replacement} == 1 ]] || replacement=''
```

... but that's a lot for an obscure edge case.  Just dropping the characters might be better anyway.

> only some of the characters in the U+0080..U+009F range seem to match `[[:cntrl:]]`.

For me, they all match in a UTF-8 locale, and none of them match in the C locale.  Tested with:

```bash
eval "chars=\$'$(for x in {8..9}{{0..9},{a..f}}; do echo -n \\u$x; done)'"
eval "expected=$(for _ in {1..32}; do echo -n s; done)"
[[ ${chars//[[:cntrl:]]/s} == $expected ]] && echo ok
```

So `[[:cntrl:]]` should work as long as Bash and vte agree on encoding, but that's assuming nobody set LC_ALL=C and forget to reset it.

> On a side note, if you have `\w` or similar in your bash prompt, bash also sends out the pathname verbatim to the terminal emulator, including escape sequences (maybe even incomplete ones). Pretty nasty if e.g. root looks around in a suspicious user's files...

Indeed :) that's how I came across this.  I knew the prompt was doing it, so I fixed my prompt and wondered why it was still acting up.

> A C utility could easily do The Right Thing: check `iswprint()` for each character (after a `setlocale()`), rather than having a hardcoded set of forbidden characters.

I'm pretty sure the character classes just use C's `isw`*class*`()` functions anyway.  But I'm not sure how `iswprint` specifically would handle the various non-printing non-control characters in Unicode (easy example: ZWNJ, or the various emoji variant selectors), so checking for control characters seems like the safer side.  Those are the only ones that can mess up the OSC sequence.

----

So here's an updated patch that should work in non-UTF-8 locales too (it's down to one line!  or it could be 3 if you think the replacement character idea above is worth including): [0001-vte.sh-Remove-control-chars-for-window-title.patch](/uploads/9eab9f523b191d4a2b85f026b35a609e/0001-vte.sh-Remove-control-chars-for-window-title.patch)

events.target_title: Recurring all-day events span too much time
Recurring all-day events span too much time

note.body:
Probably related: even when the recurring event has a `DTEND` or `DURATION`, if it falls on the first of a month, Gnome Calendar shows it for the whole preceding month in month view (but not in other views).

For example, Canada Day is July 1, and although the editor window correctly shows it as an all-day event from July 1 to July 1, the June month view shows it spread across June 1 to June 30 as well as on July 1.  (The week and year views show it correctly.)

events.target_title: update ChangeLog

note.body:
The --psm fix was not applied to the source code.
![Screenshot_from_2018-08-31_15-11-07](/uploads/77ee2ae2b82d4839e3a8a7859f557555/Screenshot_from_2018-08-31_15-11-07.png)
The current version 0.5.2 still has this bug.

Regards,

Tom

events.target_title: gitg crashes with error about style-unix.css

note.body:
I don't think that the problem lies with the style-unix.css resource. gitg reports the same on my (Fedora) system, but runs without a hitch nonetheless.
However warnings do annoy me so I did a little digging. The warning is generated because the file gitg/resources/ui/style-unix.css is an empty file. During the make process this empty file gets compressed and added to the .gresource.gitg_resources section of the gitg executable. I think the gnome loader gets upset whilst trying to uncompress an empty file.
Request to the developers: Can you put a comment in the style-unix.css and style-win32.css files, something like "/* This file is empty */".
This should fix this warning.
As far as the real problem goes, I think your problem has something to do with the GLib-GIO-CRITICAL line. As this is an assertion from within GLib we would need a stack trace to find the responsible call in gitg.
I noticed that you run a German translation. Can you confirm that the program is also unusable if run in English?

events.target_title: gitg crashes with error about style-unix.css

What would actually be needed to implement exposure of the the full tag path (as stored in the database) to the UI?
```

events.target_title: Shell crashes when deleting file by keyboard shortcut [shift]+[delete]

note.body:
Thanks @jadahl, that was the right pointer. The crash indeed stems from the auto-move-windows plugin. The plugin ensures that applications (per a set of rules) are always launched on a certain workspace. The crash only takes place if the GNOME Files window was manually moved to a workspace other than the rule says in the auto-move-windows plugin.

E.g. The rule states, that Files is to be launched on workspace 4. If I move the Files window to any other workspace than 4 and delete a file, the gnome-shell session will crash.

DBus error calling GNetworkManager.can_reach under Flatpak
DBus error calling GNetworkManager.can_reach under Flatpak

note.body:
>  However the problem with just trying to connect is that it's often not possible to tell if a failure should be reported to the user or not - is the failure to connect expected or unexpected?

I don't think this is actually a problem? After all, Geary *currently* displays an error even when the failure to connect is expected, *and* provides a `Retry` button. This would seem to be all the UI needed.

The change in behaviour I propose would be to try to connect (at startup, and when the `Retry` button is pressed) *even if* GNetworkMonitor doesn't think the network is available.

Geary wouldn't make any reconnection attempts unless either the user presses `Retry` or GNetworkMonitor notifies of a change in connection status.

> In the end, there's a bunch of things that might cause Geary to not connect, but that's an argument to make those things more robust, not to work around them in Geary

I think there's a qualitative difference between “Geary can't connect, because of some network stack problem” and “Geary *won't* connect, even though it would succeed if it tried, because of some network stack problem”. The former is annoying, but there's nothing Geary can do about it. The latter is frustrating, because - from the user's perspective - Geary is *deliberately* not working.

events.target_title: DBus error calling GNetworkManager.can_reach under Flatpak

note.body:
Hm. I'm not sure if I'm installing it correctly or not, but I'm *pretty* sure I've tested the `.flatpak` artifact from that build and it doesn't change the behaviour at all. I downloaded the [artifact](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/geary/-/jobs/97731/artifacts/download), removed my existing Geary install, and then installed it with `flatpak install --bundle $PATH_TO/geary-git.flatpak`. That's right, isn't it?

> It is a problem when you consider that if Geary did as you suggested, then users would be getting an otherwise avoidable error message very frequently (wifi/cable disconnect, resume from sleep, etc), which just makes Geary look buggy. At the moment, Geary at least won't try to connect when it's not likely to succeed, minimising these interruptions.

My memory was that being disconnected from the 'net also popped up the “we can't connect” banner, but that's just my fallible memory :).

Is it the case that Geary has *no* offline notification, then? If the user is accidentally offline, Geary will appear to work normally - except that new mail won't be downloaded and mail will be queued up to be sent, rather than sent immediately? That would also tend to make Geary look buggy?

events.target_title: Feature request: traditional (non-tablet-like) mode, disabling overlay scrollbars, warping scrolling, etc. by default
Feature request: traditional (non-tablet-like) mode, disabling overlay scrollbars, warping scrolling, etc. by default

note.body:
The problem with the current defaults is they are dysfunctional for the majority of potential users (desktop or laptop computers).
Anyone doing serious work with applications using GTK will be using a desktop or laptop computer, and not a tablet or smartphone.
Defaults should be useful for the majority of serious users.
The defaults suggested are NOT necessarily dysfunctional for tablet or smartphone users, and adding a tablet mode for defaults for such users would correct the problem.

Defaults that should be corrected include :
1) Vertical scroll bar : click above/below position indicator should move up/down 1 page instead of proportion of list.
Obviously dysfunctional if list contains thousands of items.  (eg. Common in Linux filesystems or large files)

2) Horizontal scroll bar : click left/right of position indicator should move to previous/next portion of line instead of proportion of line.
Dysfunctional with very long lines, which are not rare.
Proportional horizontal scroll has no apparent use case.

3) Disappearing scroll bars : Should not be the default.
Dysfunctional if an item takes only one line, and it appears under the position of the scroll bar.  Such an item can not be selected.
Such a function could be a minor advantage for very small screens, but only if one never needs to select a line which appears under the position of a scroll bar.
So even for very small screens, it is a rather dubious default.

Note that GTK2, as well as most other environments, had/have sane defaults for these 3 items.
Also note that GTK3 has not replaced GTK2 in many applications, largely because of the problems of the new (rather bizarre) defaults.
People don't complain about this change of defaults for nothing.
It doesn't make much sense to push users away from GTK.

note.body:
My search folder emulates Unified Inbox by searching all messages in several accounts Inboxes. I think you need to make sure your search folder is selected and highlighted in the left mailbox view. Then after you type in your search pattern and get filtered results try to clear your search pattern - at this point my search folder shows empty (no messages), until I restart Evolution mail.
BTW the workaround is to select non-search folder in left pane (some Inbox), then do search, and in this case the problem is not showing up.

events.target_title: two-finger scrolling is far too fast
two-finger scrolling is far too fast

note.body:
As some additional (maybe useful) info, the relevant source for the libinput testing tool is [here](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libinput/libinput/blob/7d0e1875701e750936b8f963db9182ca633df44e/tools/libinput-debug-gui.c#L629-635) it looks like the deltas from libinput should be interpreted as pixels.

Thanks @dboles for tagging this, that gave me a clue where to start digging into the source to start figuring out what's going on. Apologies if the description below is obvious - I'm not familiar with the GTK source so these notes are also for myself if I attempt a PR later. I got most of the way through tracing how scroll events make their way from libinput to the `GtkScrolledWindow`.

# tl;dr
1. libinput sends scroll events with `dx`/`dy` in "pixel movement of a standardized mouse"
2. Mutter divides the `dx`/`dy` values by 10 to convert to "Xi2 discrete step coordinate space"
3. GTK multiplies by page_size^(2/3) before actually scrolling the window.

To be honest I'm not sure whether the issue is wrong interpretation of the libinput values in general, or if this is specific to the fact that I'm on a HIDPI screen.

# Details

## Mutter

Mutter gets the scroll amount from libinput [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/evdev/clutter-device-manager-evdev.c#L1157-1158), and then calls [`clutter_seat_evdev_notify_scroll_continuous`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/evdev/clutter-seat-evdev.c#L734-756), which calls [`notify_scroll`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/evdev/clutter-seat-evdev.c#L605-656), which multiplies the x/y deltas by 0.1 and queues the event.

The Mutter event makes its way through the various queues and is popped off [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/clutter-main.c#L2303-2389) and passed to [`emit_pointer_event`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/clutter-main.c#L2005-2033). The next step seems to vary depending on the specifics of what's "grabbed", but I think [`clutter_actor_event`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/0210b951098c055c5ec2a2f549ae6f123943d1d2/clutter/clutter/clutter-actor.c#L13881-13957) is the main next processing step, which basically just sends the event on the `"event"` and `"scroll-event"` signals.

## Gnome Shell / Wayland
I didn't have time to trace through this code path, but in general I assume that gnome-shell receives the events from Mutter and pipes them through the Wayland API as a Wayland server.

## GDK

The wayland backend is a Wayland client that [dispatches events](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gdk/wayland/gdkeventsource.c#L109-128), calling [`_gdk_event_emit`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gdk/gdkevents.c#L166-176) calls whatever event handler is registered.

## GTK

The main GTK event entry point seems to be [`gtk_main_do_event`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkmain.c#L1698-1927), which is [configured as the GDK event handler](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkmain.c#L602).

Scroll events come in on the [`gtk_event_controller_scroll_handle_event`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkeventcontrollerscroll.c#L240-348) handler on a [`GTKEventControllerScroll`](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkEventControllerScroll.html) which sends "scroll" signals with `dx` and `dy` values as floats. It looks like the event handler is called [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkeventcontroller.c#L199-204), which is called from the more general GtkWidget code [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkwidget.c#L5142)

Scroll events are handled in [`scroll_controller_scroll`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkscrolledwindow.c#L1256), and the incoming `delta_[xy]` value is multiplied by `scroll_unit` before being applied to the adjustment that tracks the window's position in the content.

`scroll_unit` is computed [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/a28c7e88397af713b71544258b3d9a69d107229a/gtk/gtkscrolledwindow.c#L1154-1155) as `page_size^(2/3)`. I'm assuming `page_size` is in screen pixels but had trouble digging through the GTKScrollbar code to verify that.

### Other Useful References

- [libinput API docs](https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/api/)
- [libinput_event_pointer_get_axis_source docs](https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/api/group__event__pointer.html#ga2116f4bbedb61532e71d16c4f87bd4ca) showing behavior of scroll sources. In particular note that the units for scroll wheels and finger events are very different. From [here](https://wayland.freedesktop.org/libinput/doc/latest/api/group__event__pointer.html#ga29aaf86185a4c9dfa38d98b1fd4dba53) it seems that the values should be interpreted as "pixel movement of a standardized mouse"

By the way using Geary for the past 2 days and with multiple accounts it is kinda confusing. I mean I have 5 email accounts under the "Inboxes" then I have all of the 5 accounts listed again as individual "tabs" in the same panel/sidebar. Why have an "Indexes" tab when there is also a listing of all accounts in the same sidebar? Also, when I get an email and I click the Gnome notification it brings me not to Inboxes but to the Individual account -> Inbox section, and it expands the entire account with all of the folders. Very confusing. I liked Thunderbird's simple "Inbox" for all emails as that's what you basically want. Same for Sent, Draft, or Spam folders. A single unified folder for all accounts.

I think this is a must else it feels like I am managing again 5 accounts separately. 

Thanks!

Bug Gimp 2
Deprecate Shell.GenericContainer

note.body:
>  dash-to-dock extension breaks. I guess this was to be expected. I filed a bug so they know already in advance (https://github.com/micheleg/dash-to-dock/issues/799).

>This one is very concerning. Due to https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=688973, we can't really remove the Shell.GenericContainer class until GJS supports dynamic GObject classes.

I'd just like to point out that these live updates happen whenever one updates an extension through extensions.gnome.org. I ended up using the `Shell.GenericContainer` and same other terrible patterns exactly to avoid this. At each new extension release I was getting plenty of people reporting that the extension stopped working after an extension update (and typically days later realizing everything was fine after a restart).

From my perspective, as long as the extension website/browser-plugin or gnome-software (or wathever is the recommended method nowadays to install extensions) prompts the user to restart the shell instead of trying to live patch the current session, I don't see why I could not revert back to extending the GObjects directly.

events.target_title: error after upgrade
error after upgrade

note.body:
i found ın gentoo solutiom, thanx @Mike

 Mike Auty gentoo-dev 2018-07-08 17:02:19 UTC

This also means that all the gac files are installed under /usr/lib64/mono/gac, which the mono compiler then doesn't check (since it installs them its own under /usr/lib/mono/gac).  This causes packages (such as dev-util/bless) not to work because of the following error:

```
Unhandled Exception:
System.TypeLoadException: Could not load type of field 'BlessMain:DataViewBox' (0) due to: Could not load file or assembly 'gtk-sharp, Version=2.12.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=35e10195dab3c99f' or one of its dependencies. assembly:gtk-sharp, Version=2.12.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=35e10195dab3c99f type:<unknown type> member:(null) signature:<none>
[ERROR] FATAL UNHANDLED EXCEPTION: System.TypeLoadException: Could not load type of field 'BlessMain:DataViewBox' (0) due to: Could not load file or assembly 'gtk-sharp, Version=2.12.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=35e10195dab3c99f' or one of its dependencies. assembly:gtk-sharp, Version=2.12.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=35e10195dab3c99f type:<unknown type> member:(null) signature:<none>
```

This can be resolved by commenting out the `dotnet_multi_comply` line of the gtk-sharp ebuild, and it installs and bless runs correctly.  It's not clear how best to correct this, but I guess ebuilds should install their gac files into the same directory as the installed version of mono's gac?  I'm not sure how to determine that, but otherwise multilib is going to prevent most mono libraries from being usable..

events.target_title: [RFE] Support server passwords for logging in to ZNC servers

note.body:
I had a tough time setting up connections to ZNC, so I'll just add to this.

The procedure for connecting to a password protected server seems to be this:
1. Try to connect and hope that Polari hasn't changed your port to 6697 if you're using a different port.  
2. fail to connect
3. check port, it's been changed to 6697, change it and hit ok.  Don't verify it or it will be changed back to 6697.
4. Change the port on your ZNC server to 6697 because you're tired of fighting
5. Wait 1-3 minutes while it fails to connect
6. Hope that the password prompt shows up
7. enter the password (user/Servername:Password) and DO NOT HIT ENTER, but click connect
8. Repeat for the rest of your networks

Worst part is that it doesn't save the passwords on restart, so every time you log in you have to repeat the process, at least steps 4-8.

Entering the password in Empathy seems to have no effect, or it just leads to a "Network Error"


I really like the looks and native GNOME functionality of this application, so please work on improving the functionality with respect to bouncers like ZNC.  I hope I don't come across as condescending, just a little frustrated.  Again I really like this client and want it to be better, if there's any testing I can do I'd be willing to help.

note.body:
@gnumdk 
Yup, gnome-shell and mutter are at 3.30, wheras gnome-terminal is older at 3.28, I thought that might be the issue.

 @egmontkob

>  Does it occur on X11?  

No, it works fine in X11.  The Cursor turns to an outline of a rectangle when the terminal loses focus, and then fills back in.

> Does it occur with other window managers (e.g. Unity, fvwm...)?  

Tried with Openbox (X11 obviously) and the gnome-terminal cursor displays the correct behavior.

> Do you guys have steady or blinking cursor? Could you try with a steady one? E.g. change in the prefs, or echo -ne '\e[2 q', or just wait 10 seconds until blinking stops.  

I had the default, which I think is blinking.  I changed blinking to disabled and didn't see a different in behavior. No change with blinking enabled or disabled.  That echo command didn't change anything that I could discern.  Neither does reset.

> Does the cursor really vanish the moment you switch focus to another window (but gnome-terminal still remains visible)?

Yes, that describes the issue exactly.

> Does the bug occur with other vte-based terminal emulators too?

Tried with Sakura, it doesn't have the fancy "change to outline" behavior that gnome-terminal has, but the cursor stays visible when the terminal loses focus, which is the same behavior as in X11.  guake has the same behavior that I am looking for from gnome-terminal, with the cursor changing to an outline of a rectangle, but i suspect one or both are using Wayland's X emulation layer.


I should note that this happens when using gnome-shell/mutter 3.30 with the NVIDIA proprietary drivers (which just really became possible with this gnome-shell version).

note.body:
>  Rationale is: large chunks of text make everything else unreadable.

Ah, I see. That makes sense. Thanks for pointing that out.

>  There is a [configuration setting](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/tracker-miners/blob/master/src/tracker-extract/org.freedesktop.Tracker.Extract.gschema.xml.in#L38) to say how much text gets indexed, but there is none to say it won't get indexed. (It can be set to 0, but I don't think Ubuntu will change the default).

They did not change the default, this configuration is unchanged: `<range min="0" max="10485760"/>`

>  You will probably find that `tracker search "term"` and `tracker info /path/to/some/indexed/file.txt --plain-text-content` work. Could you confirm?

I confirm. It works as you stated. I also chose keywords that gave results in content using `tracker search` and compared them to both, nautilus and shell search (which are basically the same, right?). Nautilus and shell search did not find the results.

GNOME nautilus 3.26.3

note.body:
I still haven't managed to solve the problem, but I figured out I should post my experiments here in case it can be helpful.

I first tried to force a refresh by calling various `ev_view_<do_something>()` functions just after opening the new window, e.g. by adding `ev_view_previous_page(ev_window->priv->view);` on line 2298 in shell/ev-window.c. This indeed loads the document one page earlier, but this does not cause a refresh.

It also seems that the issue is more general, as it affects all actions which result in opening a *copy* on a page other that the first page, as mentionned in #290. The common feature is that they all rely on the function `ev_window_open_copy_at_dest(*window, *dest)`. This does not happen when the file is loaded on startup (which relies on a different code path).

So it seems that opening a copy always renders the first page, regardless of the `*dest` argument. Changing the view does not force an update, which hints that the update is triggered by something else, probably the input. The input also updates the view, resulting in a mere correlation.

I will try to figure out if/how does the input trigger a redraw.

events.target_title: No proper way to start multiple instances of applications anymore
No proper way to start multiple instances of applications anymore

note.body:
Ah, thanks for the explanation!

I scanned the programs in the dash and found some that indeed don't want to open new windows (gnome-control-center, chat programs, evolution).

I was confused, especially since #316 explicitly mentions that Middle-click should not open another gnome-calculator - and that is precisely how I get "more". 

Apart from that, one might want to distinguish between telling the existing process to open a new window and to launch a new process. For example sometimes I just need another emacs process (if the old one is busy ATM, I don't want to disturb the order of my buffers, ...), some other times a new window (frame) is sufficient. Heuristics do get it wrong, here, too: Middle- or Ctrl-clicking always starts a new instance.

Yes, I'm sure the image is black and white.  The original graphic isn't a composite.  It is a single screen shot, showing a 1-bit color space, but grayscale pixels.

I checked the original screen shot and see there were 2 layers in the image. I created a new sequence of steps and wasn't able to reproduce the original issue exactly, but I did find a couple of new issues. See attached document with screen shots.

I've attached a sample source image, too.  The whole exercise is to be able to take a hand drawing on a sheet of graph paper, remove the gridlines, and save as a black-and white image.

Mark

events.target_title: network-cc-panel does network rescan and shows: found duplicate: <SSID>  over and over, constant high CPU

note.body:
I'm definitely having this issue as well, and I was trying to test the patch, I'm not super confident that I've done the test correctly. Here are the steps I took:
1.  Clone source from GitLab
2.  Apply proposed patch with `git apply 0001-wifi-Only-cancel-pending-scan-if-wireless-is-disable.patch`.
3.  Verified patch was applied to source correctly
4.  Install required system dependencies from apt-get and then run `meson build/`
5.  Once that command ran with no errors I ran `ninja -C build` and that seemed to compile all targets.
6.  Then I ran `sudo ninja -C build/ install` and that seemed to copy many of the compiled targets to system-wide paths (e.g. `/usr/local`)
7.  Verified that `which gnome-control-center` pointed to a newly-compiled binary in `/usr/local/bin` instead of `/usr/bin`
8.  Ran `gnome-control-center -v`

After running the above steps, the issue does not seem to go away. I'm still left with rapid printouts of all SSIDs and 100% CPU usage. Happy to provide any other information or run any additional tests. Apologies if the above steps are not enough to verify the patch. @datashaman was talking about using debbuild to build a deb file, but I wasn't quite sure what steps would be required with this meson build system.

events.target_title: Wayland session:  Switching to another program disables the cursor indicator

note.body:
I filed the debian bug report.

**More Details:**

  * Debian Unstable
  * Wayland
  * Intel graphics; no nvidia/amd card installed

When double-clicking the window title (maximize/restore) it doesn't happen.
Changing a tab temporarily restores the cursor.

I managed to find the package(s) responsible. Downgrading fixes the problem.

**Working:**

  * `gir1.2-gtk-3.0_3.22.30-2_amd64.deb`
  * `libgtk-3-0_3.22.30-2_amd64.deb`
  * `libgtk-3-common_3.22.30-2_all.deb`

**Broken:**

  * `gir1.2-gtk-3.0_3.24.0-1_amd64.deb`
  * `libgtk-3-0_3.24.0-1_amd64.deb`
  * `libgtk-3-common_3.24.0-1_all.deb`

It happens when upgrading `libgtk-3` and `libgtk-3-common`. I included `gir` here because its new version depends on new gtk.

Debian's 3.23.2-1 works.

I'll now try to bisect the git repo. Hang on :-)

events.target_title: Media keys stop working after closing VLC

note.body:
Not sure if it's the same issue:
I use mpv (i.e. not vlc) to play music files from gnome-terminal. After some time the media keys stop working. I'm not sure how exactly I trigger it, it just happens.

I found one way that always triggers the bug:

  * play a file with mpv
  * start a second mpv and play another file, i.e. two files playing at the same time now.
  * `killall -9 mpv`
  * start a new mpv to play some file
  * media key won't work anymore

My system is debian/unstable on wayland. Gnome version appears to be a mix of 3.26-3.30; gnome-settings-daemon has version 3.28.1.

I attached the output of `dbus-monitor --session` where I followed the steps described above.
[dbus.log](/uploads/8cda182be3ec6d26c212d09f43a4e6f0/dbus.log)

events.target_title: Media keys stop working after closing VLC

note.body:
With the patch, it's harder to reproduce the issue.
Now I need to start 20x mpv in parallel and kill them all at once to trigger the bug.

I still have no idea how this really happens, though :-)

events.target_title: Media keys stop working after closing VLC

note.body:
I just tested cea632bf682760e80654df19cfef6206efca868a and I'm no longer able to reproduce the problem.

Thank you!

@buha I don't really know how to build this either. My approach is to patch+build the debian package:
```
# apt-get build-dep gnome-settings-daemon
$ apt-get source gnome-settings-daemon
$ cd gnome-settings-daemon-3.30.2/
$ (cd /path/to/git/gnome-settings-daemon; git show) | patch -p1
$ dpkg-source --commit
$ dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot
# dpkg -i gnome-settings-daemon_3.30.2-3_amd64.deb gnome-settings-daemon-common_3.30.2-3_all.deb
$ killall gsd-media-keys
```

events.target_title: Add option to disable mouse handling in gnome-terminal
Keyboard shortcuts with Ctrl + # broken

note.body:
Not sure if related. When using shortcuts, sometimes the key presses are sent to the active window too.

* I've got a shortcut on ctrl-alt-T for terminal. When I press ctrl-alt-T, "ctrl" and "alt" are sent to the active window, but "T" isn't. When I press alt-ctrl-T (which I usually do), "T" is sent as well, causing unwanted actions.
* Short cut on ctrl-end to open a browser window. "End" is sent to the active window.

**Update:** Right ctrl-key works without issues. Only left ctrl-key is affected!

My gnome version is 3.34.0 (debian sid). Previous version (without that behaviour) was mostly 3.30.

note.body:
Yeah, short filename support can be disabled (it is on mine).  In fact it is [recommended](https://guyrleech.wordpress.com/2014/04/15/ntfs-8-3-short-names-solving-the-issues/) that it is for security and performance reasons.  You can modify this setting by using `fsutil`.  See [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2003/cc778996(v=ws.10)) for more information.

I think that quotes should be used to stop that from happening, or better yet, don't use `rundll32` as [Raymond Chen has stated](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/oldnewthing/20130104-00/?p=5643).  This is quite annoying.
